text: Michael Maurice Leadbetter (1946–2009) was a rugby union international who represented England in 1970.Mike Leadbetter Profile on scrum.com ==Early life== Mike Leadbetter was born on 25 July 1946 in Southport. Mike was the younger of two brothers, and his family is one with deep roots in the Southport area, predating the construction of Southport itself. Mike was known to have been very proud of his family's roots in the fishing and farmworking of the area. However, both he and his brother Alan, who was to become a physicist, did not follow their forebears. He attended Ladybarn, a local secondary modern school, and left in 1961 aged 15, without qualifications. After a few years he began his first career in printing and followed this through a series apprenticeships leading to a diploma in management and print technology from Manchester College of Art and Design.Obituary of Mike Leadbetter in the Guardian, Drew Clode, The Guardian, Friday 24 April 2009 ==Rugby career== Leadbetter played his club rugby for Broughton Park, and made his international début on 18 April 1970 at Colombes in the France vs England match, that was won by France. Along with Broughton Park team mate Tony Neary, he was also part of a famous North West Counties team which defeated the All Blacks, 16-14, in Workington in 1972.NOWIRUL(E) TIMES ISSUE NO. 1 Described as a giant of a man, he also played 35 times for Lancashire. Leadbetter subsequently switched to rugby league going to Rochdale Hornets.Sporting memories from the Rochdale Observer 17 September 2004 ==References== Category:1946 births Category:2009 deaths Category:Alumni of Manchester Metropolitan University Category:Alumni of the University of Manchester Category:Deaths from cancer in England Category:England international rugby union players Category:English rugby league players Category:English rugby union players Category:Lancashire County RFU players Category:Sportspeople from Southport Category:Rochdale Hornets players Category:Rugby union locks
